headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, on PCs, I think you've got the same market data we have there, that the PC industry ended up maybe a little stronger than any of us anticipated, still from a unit perspective, flattish to maybe down a percent, but overall generating
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, on PCs, I think you've got the same market data we have there, that the PC industry ended up maybe a little stronger than any of us anticipated, still from a unit perspective, flattish to maybe down a percent, but overall generating about 10% DRAM bit growth going into that segment. Mobile is interesting. We continue to see pretty good bit growth by system. On average for the mobile market, probably moving to 2.4 gigabytes of DRAM and the high 30s, somewhere in the 35 to 40, maybe in the middle of that range, in terms of gigabytes of NAND. So now if you net that out, that's almost 20% DRAM bit growth per system and maybe a little north of 40% on NAND. So for that market, in aggregate, pretty strong and in particular, the values of smartphone have probably seen the highest bit growth per system of any of those segments.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Rajvindra Gill of Needham & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Rajvindra Gill of Needham & Company.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Housekeeping question first on the taxes. I think this quarter was about $30 million. Could you give us some sense of what the guidance for taxes going forward will be?
componenttext: Housekeeping question first on the taxes. I think this quarter was about $30 million. Could you give us some sense of what the guidance for taxes going forward will be?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'd guide you to low teens millions, which would be kind of low single-digit tax rate and that will change as the company's profitability changes. Obviously, when the profitability goes up, the tax rate will sequentially decline a little bit becau
componenttext: I think I'd guide you to low teens millions, which would be kind of low single-digit tax rate and that will change as the company's profitability changes. Obviously, when the profitability goes up, the tax rate will sequentially decline a little bit because of where that income is generated and should the company's profitability decline, the actual rate will creep up just a little bit.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. In the commentary, you had mentioned around 15% to 20% bit supply growth in DRAM, bearing any additional supply from competitors. Can you talk a little bit about the -- what you're seeing in terms of the transition to 18 nanometer for some of
componenttext: Okay, great. In the commentary, you had mentioned around 15% to 20% bit supply growth in DRAM, bearing any additional supply from competitors. Can you talk a little bit about the -- what you're seeing in terms of the transition to 18 nanometer for some of your competitors and is there risk in your mind in terms of additional supply coming online? Any thoughts on that would be helpful.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't have a great crystal ball as to what our competitors are doing. We read the same reports that you guys read. All of that, plus all the other internal intelligence we can generate is baked into our ranges and in the data sheet that we've provided.
componenttext: We don't have a great crystal ball as to what our competitors are doing. We read the same reports that you guys read. All of that, plus all the other internal intelligence we can generate is baked into our ranges and in the data sheet that we've provided. So I think there has been some chatter recently potentially about a few incremental wafers from one of the suppliers. Our view of that is, if that were to happen, it's a relatively minor adjustment in terms of the overall scope of the bit growth that we're projecting and it would probably not cause us to change that range that we've given you.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And last question, in terms of the balance sheet, how do you think about kind of reducing the level of debt going forward now that you're entering into a period of higher free cash flow generation. We're at about 8.5 or over -- or close
componenttext: All right, great. And last question, in terms of the balance sheet, how do you think about kind of reducing the level of debt going forward now that you're entering into a period of higher free cash flow generation. We're at about 8.5 or over -- or close to $10 billion of debt. Any thoughts on the strategy about reducing debt levels over time?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to be consistent with my prior comments, first thing I want to do is make sure we generate the cash, which we're working on feverishly and expect to make some headway on here with the results we've just shared; and then as we get to that point and
componenttext: Yes. So to be consistent with my prior comments, first thing I want to do is make sure we generate the cash, which we're working on feverishly and expect to make some headway on here with the results we've just shared; and then as we get to that point and look at the credit markets as well as a number of other factors, we will make a determination about the best way to de-lever but de-levering for the company remains an important priority as we have an expectation of increased free cash flow this year.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Timothy Arcuri of Cowen.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Timothy Arcuri of Cowen.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, I guess, Mark, you made some recent comments about China and about them potentially flooding the market if they do get access to IP. So my question is can you again remind us of sort of what your mission statement is around the potential o
componenttext: First question, I guess, Mark, you made some recent comments about China and about them potentially flooding the market if they do get access to IP. So my question is can you again remind us of sort of what your mission statement is around the potential of sharing IP or licensing IP in China?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, let me say that comments that I make in the press are sometimes not in the full context of the discussion I had. I think one of the things to think about in terms of what might or might not happen in China is that these things do tak
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, let me say that comments that I make in the press are sometimes not in the full context of the discussion I had. I think one of the things to think about in terms of what might or might not happen in China is that these things do take time. Our investment cycles take place over periods of useful life of equipment 5 years so we think in the long term, when we think about investing in our business to make sure that we're being good stewards of the shareholders' money, but anything that would happen there is going to play out over many years, and having a crystal ball as to exactly how that will play out is difficult to say. Relative to what Micron has said about our interests in China, we have a great interest in doing business in China. We have large existing operations there, including back end operations, circuit design, product engineering activities as well as software and firmware activities. So we have a lot of activity in China already from an operations perspective and we have a large number of important customers over there. So we stay fully engaged with China and continue to expect to have strong relationships there and grow our business. Relative to whether we would undertake any expansion or licensing activity in China, what we said is really as it has been, which is our job is to look for opportunities to make Micron a stronger company, and we will continue to investigate lots of options about ways to generate shareholder value whether it's in China or any other part of the world. And that's just part of us being effective managers of the company and we'll continue to do that and if we can figure out things that make the company stronger, we'll always consider that in terms of the long-term benefits and act accordingly.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And I guess I have a follow-up sort of question that was asked about some of the tax law changes coming. It seems pretty obvious that there's going to be some sort of VAT that gets added to product that's made outside the U.S. and you guys ar
componenttext: Okay. Great. And I guess I have a follow-up sort of question that was asked about some of the tax law changes coming. It seems pretty obvious that there's going to be some sort of VAT that gets added to product that's made outside the U.S. and you guys are obviously fairly exposed to that. So I'm wondering, is there any, like, contingency planning happening? And I'm sort of trying to assess the likelihood that maybe CapEx might have to be a little higher as you may have to plan for some of those contingencies?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tim, I mean, really, it's an issue of what you think any such tariffs or whatnot, how they might impact our end market, not necessarily as they directly impact Micron because typically we manufacture overseas, we sell, in many cases, overseas and then
componenttext: So Tim, I mean, really, it's an issue of what you think any such tariffs or whatnot, how they might impact our end market, not necessarily as they directly impact Micron because typically we manufacture overseas, we sell, in many cases, overseas and then it's our customers who would then be subject to any of those importation issues. So I think it's really too soon to tell what the impact of that would be because simultaneously, we're reading about a dramatic reduction of the corporate tax rate and also, the ability to repatriate billions of dollars of cash so there's a lot of moving pieces to this and I think anybody who would portend to be able to specifically predict things is probably guessing a little bit right now.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joe Moore of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joe Moore of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you can just give us some context on why the markets are so good, and I guess in particular, when I look at your shipments, have been stronger than expected, your competitors' shipments have been a bit stronger than expected and yet, I mean, o
componenttext: I wonder if you can just give us some context on why the markets are so good, and I guess in particular, when I look at your shipments, have been stronger than expected, your competitors' shipments have been a bit stronger than expected and yet, I mean, our checks and everyone's checks show this good now and staying good for a while. Can you give us any context on why the supply-demand balance has shifted so much in a favorable direction when everyone's kind of shipping more bits than the sort of long-term trend line?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: At the end of the day, Joe, it's got to be adding up all the pieces, right? And having less supply than demand. I will say that as the end markets that we ship into continue to segregate and the product has to find its way into the right -- or the wafers
componenttext: At the end of the day, Joe, it's got to be adding up all the pieces, right? And having less supply than demand. I will say that as the end markets that we ship into continue to segregate and the product has to find its way into the right -- or the wafers have to find their way in the right product at the right time for the right segment, getting that balanced exactly right segment to segment becomes difficult and therefore, I think it provides the opportunity for supply -- for pricing to react to changes in supply and demand in a way that I think is positive from a manufacturer's perspective.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful. And then secondly, in terms of your NAND planning, is there going to continue to be a long tail on the planar NAND business or do you see the whole business kind of transitioning to 3D over time?
componenttext: Great, that's helpful. And then secondly, in terms of your NAND planning, is there going to continue to be a long tail on the planar NAND business or do you see the whole business kind of transitioning to 3D over time?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's definitely a tail and it definitely exists for a long time. The question is how significant is that in terms of bits and what eventually will be the pricing in that long tail? I think that the planar bits are going to get squeezed out of a lot of
componenttext: There's definitely a tail and it definitely exists for a long time. The question is how significant is that in terms of bits and what eventually will be the pricing in that long tail? I think that the planar bits are going to get squeezed out of a lot of the end market applications as we start to generate more 3D supply as an industry. However, there will be a long tail that's probably less than 10% of the overall market. This sticks around for a long, long time and services very valuable niches. So it's a matter of getting that balance right and making sure that you have the product, have the right products in that, in those lagging nodes so you can address the right market opportunities.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Steven Fox of Cross Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Steven Fox of Cross Research.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about some of the higher margin, higher mix products, where maybe -- where you mentioned like-for-like pricing also is getting better. For example, in the Storage Business Unit, with SSDs, how are you ma
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit about some of the higher margin, higher mix products, where maybe -- where you mentioned like-for-like pricing also is getting better. For example, in the Storage Business Unit, with SSDs, how are you managing your customer expectations for longer design cycles and qualification cycles, given that product is tight now and you're saying it could be tight for a while especially as you ramp 3D NAND and maybe it had some puts and takes along the way?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's always tricky when you have customers with supply expectations, making sure that you are making the right commitments that you can deliver on while not significantly over- or under-committing. And there are lots of those segments that are sort o
componenttext: Yes. It's always tricky when you have customers with supply expectations, making sure that you are making the right commitments that you can deliver on while not significantly over- or under-committing. And there are lots of those segments that are sort of value add where you have to have long-term customer relationships where there's a certain amount of trust and I think, from Micron's perspective, that's actually an advantage for us. Our customers like us. They want us to succeed. We have a long-term history of meeting our commitments and so I think in this kind of environment, that actually plays out pretty well for us. Some of the specific segments that are value add that are pretty important: things like graphics, we grew our graphics business pretty substantially this year. In many cases, those are sole-source relationships or 2 sources at most, and a significant piece of the customers' end product and so those types of relationships, I think, are flagships for that kind of thought process. Automobile, also, I think, is another one where Micron has very significant market share, deep relationships with the customers and a trust that we're going to be there for them with the right products as markets tighten up.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And then just a quick clarification. So on Inotera, I understand you don't want to go too much deeper into the numbers but in terms of some of the synergies that are potentially ahead of you with Inotera, should we just think of it
componenttext: That's really helpful. And then just a quick clarification. So on Inotera, I understand you don't want to go too much deeper into the numbers but in terms of some of the synergies that are potentially ahead of you with Inotera, should we just think of it a bit more as the flexibility to manage bits a little bit more efficiently or is there -- should we consider that there be some meaningful cost savings that could come through to the margins down the road?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ernie. I think the best way to think about it is what Mark articulated earlier which is the cost synergies are relatively small; the real opportunity will be as we align the manufacturing capability fully to the best of Micron's fabs and that will
componenttext: This is Ernie. I think the best way to think about it is what Mark articulated earlier which is the cost synergies are relatively small; the real opportunity will be as we align the manufacturing capability fully to the best of Micron's fabs and that will provide more incremental opportunity to us than the cost savings piece.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Danely of Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Danely of Citigroup.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the mobile end market. You talked about China as being a big driver there. Can you give us any sense of how big China is as far as your mobile demand or how big of the increase it was sequentially?
componenttext: Quick question on the mobile end market. You talked about China as being a big driver there. Can you give us any sense of how big China is as far as your mobile demand or how big of the increase it was sequentially?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had pretty good growth obviously in all geographies and with a lot of different customers with the mobile business doubling. Some of that was with the market leaders but a lot of it also was in China. So eMCPs have been a great business for us. A lot o
componenttext: We had pretty good growth obviously in all geographies and with a lot of different customers with the mobile business doubling. Some of that was with the market leaders but a lot of it also was in China. So eMCPs have been a great business for us. A lot of that is in the Chinese value handsets and I don't think we want to get specific in terms of percentages but I think it's fair to say that we had strong growth in China as well as at the some of the high end smartphone manufacturers.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then Second question on another end market, PCs. So again, we all read the same stuff you do about shortages in DRAM in the PC end market. Would you say that, that is the end market where supply is tightest and any estimate of when these lead t
componenttext: Great. And then Second question on another end market, PCs. So again, we all read the same stuff you do about shortages in DRAM in the PC end market. Would you say that, that is the end market where supply is tightest and any estimate of when these lead times could be -- or these extending lead times could be relieved?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd say it's tight there but product is moving around, right? The industry is not static and what tends to happen, as the market tightens up like this, is people will sacrifice a little bit of short term margin to move product in the segments that th
componenttext: Yes. I'd say it's tight there but product is moving around, right? The industry is not static and what tends to happen, as the market tightens up like this, is people will sacrifice a little bit of short term margin to move product in the segments that they believe are longer term, more advantaged and so there's a little bit of that going on right now where perhaps, margins might actually be a little higher in PCs but people may shift production into servers because it's viewed as potentially longer-term more favorable or mobile because it's maybe a slightly more defendable market share as things change over time.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Pitzer of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I guess my first question is just around sort of your DRAM profitability versus peers. I mean, absolutely, clearly, DRAM's getting better but there's still this gap between the peers. I'm wondering if you can talk about the 1X transition for you. It
componenttext: Mark, I guess my first question is just around sort of your DRAM profitability versus peers. I mean, absolutely, clearly, DRAM's getting better but there's still this gap between the peers. I'm wondering if you can talk about the 1X transition for you. It seems like there's 2 vectors where you might be able to close that gap. One, it just seems like a better strength for you than maybe your peers, and two, correct me if I'm wrong, but most of Rex Chip, I believe, is still a 25-nanometer. So it might seem to me that as you guys move to 1X, you'll have a bigger wafer start days at 1X than you had at 20 nanometers. Am I thinking about that the right way? Or how are you thinking about it?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, at a high level, we're going to continue to outgrow the market in terms of bits, like we talked about, and we're reducing costs at a faster rate than we have over the last 3 years. So that gap will continue to narrow with the forecast we've
componenttext: First of all, at a high level, we're going to continue to outgrow the market in terms of bits, like we talked about, and we're reducing costs at a faster rate than we have over the last 3 years. So that gap will continue to narrow with the forecast we've given you. Specifically, relative to 110 series, yes, it's a good strength we have. As I mentioned, we've got a number of different products coming. Some of them are bigger shrimps than others and we're pretty particularly excited about some of the ones that come later in the fiscal year that really drive out a lot of cost in die size as opposed to some of the ones that come earlier and fill value-added potential segments or specific power performance attributes that the customers are looking for. Beyond that, I think it's fair to say that we should get a good bang for the buck on this technology transition, not only because it's a substantial shrink, but also because a chunk of it -- a large chunk of it's happening in Taichung so we're actually transitioning capacity from 25-nanometer all the way down to 1X. So it's -- as we did with 20-nanometer in Hiroshima and Inotera, and a big chunk of that capacity at Inotera was a double hop from 30-nanometer to 20-nanometer, this will be a double hop from 25 to 1X at the Taichung fab and so there's a pretty good bang for the buck there.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Then guys, as my follow up, you're still endorsing the 2-year CAGRs for bit growth in NAND and DRAM for you. Ernie, I know you don't want to get into quarter by quarter but I'm kind of curious as how we should think about linearity of that
componenttext: That's helpful. Then guys, as my follow up, you're still endorsing the 2-year CAGRs for bit growth in NAND and DRAM for you. Ernie, I know you don't want to get into quarter by quarter but I'm kind of curious as how we should think about linearity of that bit growth from here on out for this fiscal year for both DRAM and NAND? And I kind of asked the question because, specifically for the DRAM, if it's kind of a linear growth rate, it just seems like the February numbers are still embedding some very conservative assumptions around pricing given how good the environment is. So how do I think about that dynamic?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're going to see us make some steady quarter on quarter growth but I don't think in DRAM, particularly, you're going to see it continue at the levels that you've seen it for the last couple of quarters. And I think the best guidance we can prov
componenttext: I think you're going to see us make some steady quarter on quarter growth but I don't think in DRAM, particularly, you're going to see it continue at the levels that you've seen it for the last couple of quarters. And I think the best guidance we can provide is that we're going to be roughly year-on-year to get to our targets, we're going to need to be at or slightly above 50% in terms of bit growth year-on-year. I mean, we've just given you a pretty big number for Q1. So that math is getting easier and easier to work out. I would also tell you, relative to some of the pricing, you will note that we widened our revenue guidance range a little bit and that's reflective of a bigger business and the fact that we realize the pricing environment continues to be dynamic so we did try to reflect our best thinking in the guidance that we've provided to you.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jagadish Iyer of Summit Redstone.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jagadish Iyer of Summit Redstone.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question, Mark or Ernie, how should we think about cost reduction for Gen2 NAND versus your Gen1? And when do you think it might become visible for you guys?
componenttext: So first question, Mark or Ernie, how should we think about cost reduction for Gen2 NAND versus your Gen1? And when do you think it might become visible for you guys?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, on a full conversion, think of it as roughly doubling the bits for wafer and think of a cost down in the range of greater than 30%. So it's a big transition but it's also, as we mentioned, it won't start to become significant until later in fis
componenttext: Yes. Well, on a full conversion, think of it as roughly doubling the bits for wafer and think of a cost down in the range of greater than 30%. So it's a big transition but it's also, as we mentioned, it won't start to become significant until later in fiscal 2017.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then on the DRAM front, I just wanted to find out if there's going to be any meaningful wafer capacity additions from Micron in fiscal '17. Is there a fab where you have some additional headroom for you to invest or should you invest in new greenfie
componenttext: Okay. Then on the DRAM front, I just wanted to find out if there's going to be any meaningful wafer capacity additions from Micron in fiscal '17. Is there a fab where you have some additional headroom for you to invest or should you invest in new greenfield?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're very focused on the technology upgrades that we were talking about with John a minute ago. That's where we get the biggest bang for the buck. We do have some cleaning space around the network but we have no plans to add new wafers this year.
componenttext: We're very focused on the technology upgrades that we were talking about with John a minute ago. That's where we get the biggest bang for the buck. We do have some cleaning space around the network but we have no plans to add new wafers this year.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Harlan Sur of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Harlan Sur of JPMorgan.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Solid job on the quarterly execution, and also congrats on the 600 basis point inflection in NAND gross margins. If we focus on this, clearly, 3D bit crossover was a big driver going forward. As I think about more cost per bit decline, you still have the
componenttext: Solid job on the quarterly execution, and also congrats on the 600 basis point inflection in NAND gross margins. If we focus on this, clearly, 3D bit crossover was a big driver going forward. As I think about more cost per bit decline, you still have the benefits of continued higher 3D mix, higher TLC 3D mix on Gen1. Question here is, when should we expect TLC 3D crossover with 3D MLC? Is that going to be this quarter?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we're -- it definitely will be this quarter in aggregate. We expect TLC to be greater than 50% of the 3D bits.
componenttext: Yes, we're -- it definitely will be this quarter in aggregate. We expect TLC to be greater than 50% of the 3D bits.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then at the product level, based off of third-party estimates, the enterprise SSD market's about a $10 billion market, growing at about 25% year-over-year for the next few years. You guys have low single-digits market share while your JV partne
componenttext: Great. And then at the product level, based off of third-party estimates, the enterprise SSD market's about a $10 billion market, growing at about 25% year-over-year for the next few years. You guys have low single-digits market share while your JV partner has about 35% market share here, high-capacity status, the biggest portion of this market, you just announced the 5100 series, that's 3D TLC. Can you guys just give us a sense on when you're going to start shipping this in volume production? Are the large hyperscale guys the big customers here? And just given what looks to be a step up in the road maps and maybe some of your customer feedback, are you guys anticipating growing your share here in the enterprise space in 2017?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We definitely plan to grow our share. As you point out, the fact that our share is relatively small in those segments today means there's a lot of opportunity. We do have what we think is a much better product portfolio now. It's got a lot of custome
componenttext: Yes. We definitely plan to grow our share. As you point out, the fact that our share is relatively small in those segments today means there's a lot of opportunity. We do have what we think is a much better product portfolio now. It's got a lot of customer excitement and eagerness, and we think that we're well-positioned with long-term customers who really want to buy from Micron. So yes.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Romit Shah of Nomura.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Romit Shah of Nomura.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask a question about gross margin, that the guidance is much better than expected. I'm just -- I'm curious, how would you suggest we think about the gross margin potential of Micron, considering your mix, cost road map and whatever price
componenttext: I just wanted to ask a question about gross margin, that the guidance is much better than expected. I'm just -- I'm curious, how would you suggest we think about the gross margin potential of Micron, considering your mix, cost road map and whatever price based on pricing assumptions are you making? Is last cycle's peak gross margin sort of a good guidepost for us or are you thinking about it differently?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a question that's got 1,000 relative comparisons in it and what I would tell you is look, we are a different company than at the last peak. We have a higher mix of NAND. We have a technology progression that we're trying to share with you. So certa
componenttext: That's a question that's got 1,000 relative comparisons in it and what I would tell you is look, we are a different company than at the last peak. We have a higher mix of NAND. We have a technology progression that we're trying to share with you. So certainly, I think we've outlined our cost reductions over the next 3 quarters or so. If you take the broad guidance we've provided, we've provided bit growth targets and you get to overlay a pricing environment and from that, derive a gross margin profile. But I would expect, if you have a similar market, you're going to continue to see opportunity for us to expand our gross margins.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I also ask you, what's the net operating -- the NOL balance today and can you just educate us on restrictions in terms of utilizing that asset against future tax provisions?
componenttext: Can I also ask you, what's the net operating -- the NOL balance today and can you just educate us on restrictions in terms of utilizing that asset against future tax provisions?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's somewhere in the $4 billion plus or minus range and one of the reasons that -- and we're very focused on protecting that NOL, which is the reason we've put our NOL rights plan in place and it's in the proxy now and up for a shareholder review as
componenttext: Yes. It's somewhere in the $4 billion plus or minus range and one of the reasons that -- and we're very focused on protecting that NOL, which is the reason we've put our NOL rights plan in place and it's in the proxy now and up for a shareholder review as well. And we intend to do everything we can to continue to preserve our ability to use that because these are exactly the times that we want to have the ability to do that.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does the $4 billion balance mean that, whatever the tax rate is, 5% is sort of the right way to think about your rate over the next several years?
componenttext: Does the $4 billion balance mean that, whatever the tax rate is, 5% is sort of the right way to think about your rate over the next several years?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, because that would apply to U.S. income and earnings, which are taxed, unfortunately, at a much higher rate than 5%.
componenttext: No, because that would apply to U.S. income and earnings, which are taxed, unfortunately, at a much higher rate than 5%.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you can only utilize it for U.S. income?
componenttext: Okay. So you can only utilize it for U.S. income?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's right.
componenttext: That's right.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Wong of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Wong of Wells Fargo.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an idea of what you expect your debt and cash equivalents might be at the end at the February quarter following the Inotera payments? And apart from CapEx, are there any significant post acquisition cash charges for restructuring or anythi
componenttext: Can you give us an idea of what you expect your debt and cash equivalents might be at the end at the February quarter following the Inotera payments? And apart from CapEx, are there any significant post acquisition cash charges for restructuring or anything else to do with Inotera?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there are no significant restructuring charges anticipated. We borrowed $2.5 billion relative to Inotera so we would expect that to be somewhere -- total debt to be somewhere in the range of 12 -- high 12, maybe $13 billion plus or minus. There's a few
componenttext: So there are no significant restructuring charges anticipated. We borrowed $2.5 billion relative to Inotera so we would expect that to be somewhere -- total debt to be somewhere in the range of 12 -- high 12, maybe $13 billion plus or minus. There's a few little moving pieces around. We're sitting here with cash, this quarter, at $4.3 billion. There was a cash component to the transaction of about $500 million and then we'll generate operating cash flow and free cash flow in fiscal Q2, which we don't guide. So the result of that will be sort of where we'll be at cash but I would expect, based on everything I know, that it's reasonable to think flat or higher.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kevin Cassidy of Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kevin Cassidy of Stifel.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: On your transition to the 1X DRAM process, will this be any different than past transitions, meaning are you going to be coming out into the PC market first and then mobile, or will this be targeted for certain markets?
componenttext: On your transition to the 1X DRAM process, will this be any different than past transitions, meaning are you going to be coming out into the PC market first and then mobile, or will this be targeted for certain markets?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've got a -- as I mentioned earlier, Kevin, we've got a broad spectrum of products. We're trying to make sure we get as many of them qualified early in the ramp as possible this time and do a slightly better job than we did at 20 nanometer. So actually,
componenttext: We've got a -- as I mentioned earlier, Kevin, we've got a broad spectrum of products. We're trying to make sure we get as many of them qualified early in the ramp as possible this time and do a slightly better job than we did at 20 nanometer. So actually, we have sort of mobile and compute products coming and then we have sort of additional costs reduced and broader market applications behind that.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then on your 3D XPoint, you said you'd have your first revenue in 2017. Can you say what end market that would be?
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then on your 3D XPoint, you said you'd have your first revenue in 2017. Can you say what end market that would be?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Newman of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Newman of Bernstein.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the great quarter. Question really about the -- about where we are in the cycle right now. Things look really great on pricing. I wonder -- because you also, you mentioned on inventory, on the DRAM maintenance level, also looks good, do you ha
componenttext: Congrats on the great quarter. Question really about the -- about where we are in the cycle right now. Things look really great on pricing. I wonder -- because you also, you mentioned on inventory, on the DRAM maintenance level, also looks good, do you have any comments on the inventory level of the customers? I'm wondering, particularly on the Chinese, Mark, I know you have been buying quite a lot of memory through this second half of 2016, and I'm just wondering if you're seeing any double ordering, any excess inventory on the customer side, anything at all that makes you a little bit concerned of excess inventory, either on the chip side or on the finished product side, especially on handsets?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really, Mark. We've heard rumors along the lines of those that you're alluding to, I believe, but we can't -- I can't validate those for you. Certainly in most market segments, it's very, very tight and any time you have that, and customers start gett
componenttext: Not really, Mark. We've heard rumors along the lines of those that you're alluding to, I believe, but we can't -- I can't validate those for you. Certainly in most market segments, it's very, very tight and any time you have that, and customers start getting nervous about are they potentially going to go line down, et cetera, you always start to be concerned that people are just trying to get a little bit ahead of it and build an inventory. I think that's only natural. I think we're doing a pretty good job of trying to allocate this product where it's absolutely most needed and so I don't think too many people are building up too much inventory.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if you think about back to the previous -- back in 2014, at the moment, this feels very much like 2014. Pricing's strong, demand's good, supply demand remains pretty tight. Anything different if you compare between now and then? Because cl
componenttext: Great. And then if you think about back to the previous -- back in 2014, at the moment, this feels very much like 2014. Pricing's strong, demand's good, supply demand remains pretty tight. Anything different if you compare between now and then? Because clearly, what happened in 2015 and '16 wasn't quite what we were hoping for in terms of supply-demand balance in pricing. I'm just wondering if you had any comments on what is different between the previous cycle. Clearly, the industry is a lot better than the past but the question is how much. And I'm just trying to ask if you have any particular thoughts of this time versus 2014 in particular.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's -- I think that part of what happened in the last -- latter end -- latter stage of the last cycle, where perhaps a little bit of a miscalculation by one of the suppliers that they probably learned from, so there's that. The biggest change str
componenttext: I think it's -- I think that part of what happened in the last -- latter end -- latter stage of the last cycle, where perhaps a little bit of a miscalculation by one of the suppliers that they probably learned from, so there's that. The biggest change structurally in the market, though, really is the fact that the products are going in a much broader set of end markets or are much more broadly distributed. Now we're 3 or 4 years on from where we were in the last cycle and I think that does make a difference. On top of that -- and Mark, I'll add one more piece to that, which is, sort of a long-term trend that we talked about in the past in terms of slowing technology migrations means that competitors in the marketplace are likely doing math with numbers that are changing less rapidly than they used to be. So both from a demand and a supply perspective, as those numbers get smaller and the slope gets smaller and the rate of change, it gets a little bit easier to do the math and it keeps things in balance. And then finally, as you layer on what's going on with NAND right now from a demand perspective, just explosive, I think, is probably the right word in terms of demand and elastic as well. And so I think there's may be some insulation there that wasn't there last time around.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016

componenttext: XPoint.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really, no. The question was asked, who are we going to ship to first? Well, we're not going to tell you who we're going to ship to first but longer term, it's storage, it's data center and it's mobile applications, all of those. I think early on, it'
componenttext: Not really, no. The question was asked, who are we going to ship to first? Well, we're not going to tell you who we're going to ship to first but longer term, it's storage, it's data center and it's mobile applications, all of those. I think early on, it's pure additive demand to that overall memory market. So we get 2 or 3 years in and have more substantial ramp going on in the cost reduction, yes, I think it will, over time, cannibalize part of the DRAM business.

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And second question. In terms of the NAND channel inventory, how is that looking like right now?
componenttext: And second question. In terms of the NAND channel inventory, how is that looking like right now?

headline: Micron Technology, Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very tight. Very tight. Customers are quite concerned.
componenttext: Very tight. Very tight. Customers are quite concerned.
